Dimensioned Quantities

Let the compiler enforce the dimensional validity of your calculations. More...


Classes

struct  Quantity< Dimensions, Precision >
 Template class to define a data type with appropriate dimensions. More...

Namespaces

namespace  PhysicalModeling::DimensionedQuantities::dims
 Dimension types, to use as template parameters for Quantity. All dimensions that are not a base, irreducible dimension are defined as products of powers of other dimensions.

Typedefs

typedef double DefaultPrecision
 Default precision type, for use when no precision is specified for a dimensioned quantity.

Complete type names using SI units

These are for convenience only - the standard Quantity template may always be used interchangeably with these.

typedef Quantity< mass > Kilograms
typedef Quantity< length > Meters
typedef Quantity< force > Newtons
typedef Quantity< speed > MetersPerSecond
typedef Quantity< accel > MetersPerSecondPerSecond
typedef Quantity< torque > NewtonMeters
typedef Quantity< stiffness > NewtonsPerMeter

Detailed Description

Let the compiler enforce the dimensional validity of your calculations.

Allows specification of dimensions (mass, length, etc) as a part of a C++ type, which will then enforce dimensional compatibility (can't add a mass and a length) and allow for dimensional analysis-type computation (mass times acceleration produces a force).

For example, here is some code using the basic Quantity<> template class:

    #include <PhysicalModeling/DimensionedQuantities.h>
    namespace dq = PhysicalModeling::DimensionedQuantities; // Namespace alias, for tidier code
    dq::Quantity<dq::dims::mass> m(20.0); // mass of 20 (think kg)
    dq::Quantity<dq::dims::accel> a(9.810); // accel of 9.81 (think m/s^2 - accel due to gravity)
    dq::Quantity<dq::dims::force> F = m * a; // Newton's second law, F should contain ~197.4
    std::cout << m + a << std::endl; // won't compile: m and a have incompatible dimensions for addition

If you'll be working in SI units (recommended), you might like using the typedefs at the bottom, which include Meters, Seconds, Kilograms, and so on. Then, you can do the above computation: 

    #include <PhysicalModeling/DimensionedQuantities.h>
    namespace dq = PhysicalModeling::DimensionedQuantities; // Namespace alias, for tidier code
    dq::Kilograms m(20.0);
    dq::MetersPerSecondPerSecond a(9.810);
    dq::Newtons F = m * a;

Remarks:
The code itself is based on the information included in the Boost MPL documentation/tutorial, but extended for physical modeling and for having a default precision. If you want to go beyond just using this header as-is, you can find information on the basic principles in use at http://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_43_0/libs/mpl/doc/tutorial/dimensional-analysis.html

Typedef Documentation

typedef double DefaultPrecision

Default precision type, for use when no precision is specified for a dimensioned quantity.

If the preprocessor symbol PHYSICALMODELING_DEFAULT_PRECISION is defined, it will be used as the default precision, otherwise the built-in double type will be used.

Function Documentation

Quantity<D, T> PhysicalModeling::DimensionedQuantities::operator+ ( const Quantity< D, T > &  l,
const Quantity< D, T > &  r 
) [inline]

Addition operator for quantities with dimensions.

Prevents addition of quantities with incompatible dimensions, and allows addition of quantities with equal dimensions.

Subtraction operator for quantities with dimensions.

Prevents subtraction of quantities with incompatible dimensions, and allows subtraction of quantities with equal dimensions.
